abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Khairpur Tile Drainage and
            Irrigated Farming Development Project in Pakistan was
            achieved. As should be expected with a pilot project, many
            implementation delays were experienced -- some were
            bureaucratic; however most were associated with the
            "learning process" of applying a new technology.
            There were "teething problems",(i.e. compensation,
            equipment, etc). associated with these transfers. Eventually
            these problems were overcome and the Training and Visits
            (T&V) extension program became fully operational. The
            International Development Association (IDA) was instrumental
            in the successful completion of the project. Lessons learned
            and experience gained from this project specifically relate
            to: viability of horizontal (pipe) drainage in alleviating
            waterlogging; (b) efficiency of trenching machines in
            installing large collector drains; and (c)the need for a
            well designed and implemented monitoring and evaluation
            program. An appropriate Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E)
            program must be designed and carried out in all water sector
            project and this is particularly true of subsurface drainage
            projects. M&E is essential in determining project
            results and a monitoring program is essential in determining
            adequacy of design and installed system and as an aid in
            efficiently operating and maintaining the completed project.
